pred_note:
clinical note   
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
  The patient came into the clinic anxious after having been informed that she tested positive for Hepatitis C. She had no prior knowledge of this condition and had a previous history of IV drug use and alcohol abuse that she had since quit, as well as smoking. She also mentioned feeling tired at the end of the day.   
PHYSICAL EXAM
  The patient's vitals were all within the normal range. She was in no distress and had no jaundice. Upon examination, her heart was regular with a two out of six systolic murmur, but her lungs, abdomen and musculoskeletal system were all normal.   
RESULTS
  Based on her initial blood work, the patient tested positive for Hepatitis C with an elevated AST at 39. However, her ALT albumin and total bilirubin levels were normal.   
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
  Additional blood work, including a hep C RNA and HCV genotype will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis. An ultrasound will also be performed to determine the severity of her liver disease. The patient should also arrange to have her family screened for the virus. Once all of the results are collected, a treatment plan will be developed based on the severity of the condition. The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in three weeks.

The patient's vitals were all within the normal range. She was in no distress and had no jaundice. Upon examination, her heart was regular with a two out of six systolic murmur, but her lungs, abdomen and musculoskeletal system were all normal. Based on her initial blood work, the patient tested positive for Hepatitis C with an elevated AST at 39. However, her ALT albumin and total bilirubin levels were normal.

Additional blood work, including a hep C RNA and HCV genotype will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis. An ultrasound will also be performed to determine the severity of her liver disease. The patient should also arrange to have her family screened for the virus. Once all of the results are collected, a treatment plan will be developed based on the severity of the condition. The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in three weeks.
gt_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Hepatitis C.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports personal history of intravenous drug use over 15 years ago. She is currently smoking 1-2 cigarettes per day, previously 1 to 1.5 packs per day. She also has a history of heavy alcohol use, but now drinks approximately 1 beer per day, more on the weekends.

FAMILY HISTORY

Patient reports family history significant for hypertension, diabetes, and depression.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.

All other systems were reviewed and are negative.

VITALS

Vitals look good today.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional
- General Appearance: in no apparent distress.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate. 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, unchanged.

Gastrointestinal
- Examination of Abdomen: No masses or tenderness. No hepatosplenomegaly.
- Auscultation: Bowel sounds normal.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No edema.

Integumentary
- Examination: No signs of jaundice.

RESULTS

HCV antibody: Positive
AST: 39
ALT: Within normal limits
Albumin: Within normal limits
Bilirubin, total: Within normal limits

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Hepatitis C.
- Medical Reasoning: Her recent blood work revealed a positive HCV antibody. She does have a history of intravenous drug use, but she has not used drugs in over 15 years.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of hepatitis C in detail. I advised the patient to have her spouse and children tested for hepatitis C as well.
- Medical Treatment: I'm going to order additional labs including a hepatitis C RNA and HCV genotype to confirm the diagnosis, as well as a Fibroscan to assess the severity of the condition.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 weeks.
